TitleMain.Title: 20th Zola Cooper memorial clinicopathologic seminar in dermatology 1973

Author.CollectiveName: Zola Cooper Memorial Clinicopathologic Seminar in Dermatology

PhysicalDescription.Extent: 240 slides : col. ; 2x2 in. & 2 cassettes (2-track. mono. ca. 60 min. ea.) and guide.

OtherAbstract.AbstractText: This program presents twenty-nine cases which illustrate certain dermatological conditions. The history, histopathology, physical findings, laboratory data, clinical course and treatment of almost every case are included in the text. Case presentations illustrating the following are included: 1) sporotrichosis, localized form. 2) mycobacterium marinum infection resembling sporotrichosis. 3) deep fungal infection (Botrytis species cultured on several occasions). 4) pyoderma of unknown etiology resembling blastomycosis. 5) Kyrle's disease. 6) nodular hidradenoma (solid and cystic hidradenoma). 7) nevocanthoendothelioma in an unusual location. 8) acantholytic herpetriform dermatitis (autoimmune vesiculobullous disease). 9) toxic epidermal necrolysis. 10) epidermolysis bullosa acquisita. 11) subcorneal pustular dermatosis. 12) lipoid proteinosis. 13) annular necrobiosis lipoidica. 14) discord lupus erythematosus initially resembling secondary syphilis, with features of lichen planus. 15) lymphocytoma cutis of Bäfverstedt (Spiegler-Fendt sarcoid). 16) a. acute lymphoblastic leukemia; b. malignant reticulosis of the skin. 17) reticulum-cell sarcoma. 18) spindle-cell malignant melanoma. 19) diagnosis of Hutchinson's freckle grading into a nodular malignant melanoma, with a nonpigmented nodule of melanoma included in the general lesion. 20) pigmented basal-cell carcinoma. 21) resolving keratoacanthoma within the red portion of a tattoo. 22) hemangiopericytoma. 23) mucinous carcinoma of the scalp. 24) squamous-cell carcinoma, erythroplasia of Queyrat, and balanitis xerotica obliterans of the penis. 25) plasma-cell balanitis (zoon). 26) granuloma faciale reaction associated with skin cancer. 27) epidermodysplasia verruciformis. 28) nocardiosis. 29) subepidermal calcified nodule.

TitleMain.Title: Grooming, bathing, and skin care for the physically disabled

PublicationInfo.Imprint: Minneapolis : The Institute : [for loan or sale by its Publication-Audiovisuals Office], c1979.
PublicationInfo.Publisher: The Institute : [for loan or sale by its Publication-Audiovisuals Office],

PhysicalDescription.Extent: 56 slides : col. ; 2x2 in. & cassette (2-track. mono. 18 min.) and script.

OtherAbstract.AbstractText: (Critical) This program discusses the use of simple self-care measures and devices for the physically disabled in the performance of personal hygiene. Care of the hair, nails teeth and dentures, shaving, bathing, and simple preventive skin care are demonstrated. The intended audience is ambiguous; the content is sometimes directed to the patient and sometimes to health care personnel. Overall, the slides and audio are of excellent quality; however, they are not clearly coordinated and the effort to correlate them may be distracting. The safety of some of the demonstrated techniques and the efficiency of some devices is debatable. This program is recommended for use with reservations.

OtherAbstract.AbstractText: This unedited raw footage shows some of the scientists who attended the 13th International Congress of Physiology (August 1929) at Harvard Medical School in Boston, Massachusetts. Included are scientists who did pioneer work in tissue culture, circulation, conditioned reflexes, vitamins, etc. Also included is a panoramic view of the Harvard Medical School and scenes of scientists eating and smoking. This footage contains more physicians than the edited version of this film called: Photographs of some of the scientists who attended the XIIth International Congress of Physiology at Boston, August 1929.

TitleMain.Title: [TV spot announcements]
TitleMain.OtherInformation: [motion picture] / American Dental Association, et al.

PhysicalDescription.Extent: Answer print : 1 film reel of 1 (700 ft.) : sd., b&w with col. ; 16 mm.
Duplication copy : 1 videocassette of 1 (Betacam SP) (20 min.) : sd., b&w ; 1/2 in.
Viewing copy : 1 videocassette of 1 (VHS) (20 min.) : sd., b&w with col. ; 1/2 in.
Viewing copy : 1 videodisc of 1 (DVD) (20 min.) : sd., b&w with col. ; 4 3/4 in.

OtherAbstract.AbstractText: This reel is comprised of 16 short films on dental health, some or all of them to be used as television spot announcements. Some are labeled as public service announcements from the American Dental Association. The films are, briefly: 1. A little girl demonstrates good brushing technique, proper care of the teeth after meals as a narrator admonishes children to care for their teeth. 2. A teenage boy is shown eating nutritious foods and candy as a narrator explains that good foods are necessary for good dental health and that sugar causes tooth decay. 3. A toddler, getting his first molar, is shown eating, brushing his teeth, and sitting in the dentist's chair. The narrator stresses the importance of caring properly for the first teeth as a step toward life-long dental health. 4. A mother and her grade-school age daughter brush their teeth together as the narrator urges the viewer to start dental care early to insure lifetime dental health. The preceding films are in live action. The following films are animated. 5. Over animation of people with and without dentures, a narrator urges people who have lost teeth to see their dentist and have dentures made. 6. An animated sequence called "A Toothsome Tale" outlines good brushing technique. 7. Nutritional guidelines to promote dental health are presented. 8. "Liz the Quiz Whiz" stresses the importance of the first teeth. 9. The effects of the loss of teeth on nutrition, digestion, and social success are contrasted with the advantages of wearing partial dentures. 10. The importance of the first teeth is explained. 11. A good cowboy and bad bandit (tooth decay) film stresses brushing after every meal. 12.Suzie wins a trophy for her beautiful teeth and her mother wins one for taking good care of Suzie's first teeth. 13. Take care of your teeth so they will last a lifetime is the message in this segment. 14. Teens with healthy teeth "really rate." 15. In "Billy meets Tommy Tooth," Tommy Tooth, the first tooth Billy has lost, lectures Billy on taking care of the tooth that will replace Tommy. Good nutrition is emphasized, especially eating apples as a snack and as a tooth cleaner after meals. 16. "The Case of the Missing Tooth" stresses the importance of replacing lost permanent teeth so that the remaining teeth maintain their correct positions.

NLMCatalogRecord.GeneralNote: Production companies vary with each announcement and include: American Dental Association, Cleveland Health Council, the National Apple Institute and Society for Visual Education (for the Apple Growers of America), and Cal Dunn Studios.

TitleMain.Title: Tooth truth with Harv and Marv

PublicationInfo.Imprint: United States : A. Higgins Productions, c1976.

PhysicalDescription.Extent: 1 reel of 1 (395 ft.) : sd., col. ; 16 mm. answer print safety.

OtherAbstract.AbstractText: Marv dreams about a magic rabbit that teaches him why we should not eat foods containing a lot of sugar: The rabbit explains how saliva and germs combine on teeth to form plaque; how sugar in food mixes with plaque to form acid. Acid is what eats into our teeth and causes cavities. Harv and Marv visit children who are having lunch and observe that they are eating foods that are not only good for them but also healthful for their teeth and gums. They are avoiding sweet foods that are harmful to teeth, such as candy, cake, and pie. Harv and Marv next visit a dentist's office where the dentist is showing Debbie and Steve the correct way to brush and floss, and explaining the importance of removing plaque from the teeth. He shows them the kind of toothbrush to buy. Using a large model of teeth, he demonstrates the most effective way to brush. He also shows the correct use of dental floss, and stresses the importance of cleaning teeth every day. He explains that dental floss is a special kind of string that will clean the plaque from between the teeth and from under the gums where the toothbrush cannot reach. Harv is convinced that most boys and girls don't care about cleaning their teeth; they let their teeth take care of themselves. Marv disagrees, however, and proves they nearly always want to brush and floss correctly in order to avoid cavities and have strong and healthy teeth when they grow up.

TitleMain.Title: Procedures for the collection of arterial blood specimens : approved standard
TitleMain.OtherInformation: / Susan Blonshine, Rebecca Alberti, Raymond L. Olesinski.

Author.CollectiveName: National Committee for Clinical Laboratory Standards.

Abstract.AbstractText: Collection of a blood specimen, as well as its handling and transport, are key factors in the accuracy of clinical laboratory analysis and ultimately in delivering quality patient care. NCCLS document H11-A3--Procedures for the Collection of Arterial Blood Specimens; Approved Standard--Third Edition serves a dual purpose: to reduce the potential hazard to the patient and to maintain the integrity of the arterial blood specimen. Collecting arterial blood is not only technically difficult but also imposes a degree of risk for the patient. Arterial blood is also one of the most sensitive of the specimens sent to the clinical laboratory for analysis; this standard will be particularly valuable to those involved in blood specimen collection such as clinical laboratory directors, physicians, physicians in training, nurses, respiratory therapists, medical technologists, exercise physiologists, phlebotomists, and perfusionists.

TitleMain.Title: Analysis of medical care capability for the Department of Veterans Affairs. Final rept

Author.CollectiveName: United States. Department of Veterans Affairs.

OtherAbstract.AbstractText: The report contains an analysis of the medical care capability in the communities surrounding the Veteran Affairs Medical Centers, including all potential sources of health care both VA and non-VA. Three sections assess the provision of medical services: (1) across four VA regions; (2) throughout 5 major VA metropolitan areas with a high concentration of VA facilities; and (3) in selected VA Medical Centers located within all four geographic regions. The Commission used these reports to produce a study that will map out a strategy for the VA for 10, 20, or 30 years from now to maximize the efficiency of veterans medical care.

TitleMain.Title: Analysis of Medicare customary charge distributions. Final rept

Author.CollectiveName: United States. Health Care Financing Administration.

OtherAbstract.AbstractText: The goals of the project were to test the feasibility of effectively and efficiently acquiring physician pricing data on customary charges. In the initial phase, data files containing customary, prevailing and reasonable charge (CPR) pricing and providing identification information were obtained directly from Part B carriers. The second phase entailed acquiring additional data files on Part B claims experience for the original study states. The third phase expanded the study to include pricing and claims data from additional states. The final phase involved simulations of the aggregate and redistributive effects of implementing the Medicare Fee Schedule in 1992 and acquiring and validating updated carrier CPR pricing files.

TitleMain.Title: 3D ultrasound display using optical tracking

Author.CollectiveName: University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill. Dept. of Computer Science.
Conference on Visualization in Biomedical Computing

PublicationInfo.Imprint: Chapel Hill, NC : University of North Carolina, 1990.

OtherAbstract.AbstractText: A method is presented to capture a 3D ultrasound volume from a series of 2D cross-sectional images obtained with a conventional B-mode scanner. We use optical tracking of the ultrasound transducer to located the digitized sections within the volume. In this paper we described a simple optical tracking technique which uses two conventional video cameras and stereopsis, and discuss its freedom-of-motion effects on reconstruction and visualization. We are in the process of investigating its utility in an experiment imaging a human fetus. This technique is but a pilot forerunner of optical methods to be employed in a project whose goal is to achieve real-time interactive display of 3D ultrasound.

TitleMain.Title: Calcium nutrition in the elderly

Abstract.AbstractText: Aging begins as growth and maturity end and is characterized by tendencies toward involution and functional impairment. The result is a progressive compromising of the capacity to adapt to an ever-varying environment. Calcium (Ca) metabolism and dietary Ca requirements in human aging are of interest not only from a general gerontological viewpoint, but also because of possible involvement in the etiology of age-related osteoporosis.

TitleMain.Title: A bacteria antibiotic system in space

PublicationInfo.Imprint: Noordwijk, The Netherlands : ESA Publ. Div., 1995.

NLMCatalogRecord.Affiliation: Groupe de Recherches cliniques de Radiobiologie et Biologie gravitationnelle, Université Paul Sabatier, Toulouse, France.

OtherAbstract.AbstractText: In order to evaluate the effects of space factors, weightlessness and cosmic rays, we undertook the Antibio 23F experiment aboard the Space Shuttle 'Discovery' during the International Microgravity Laboratory (IML-1) mission from 22 to 30 January 1992. The purpose of this experiment was to study the effects of various antibiotic concentrations (dihydrostreptomycin) on bacterial growth behaviour and to investigate antibiotic binding by means of a radioactive tracer such as tritium (3H). Antibiotic penetration is a determinant factor of its antibacterial action. Energetic and kinetic phenomena are involved. Three successive phases in aminoglycoside antibiotic transportation within bacteria are described: the first phase is very fast and results in the fixation of aminoglycoside on the cytoplasmic membrane after the way through porins for Gram-negative bacteria such as E. coli. It is followed by two phases that need energy and induce fixation on the ribosomes. This phenomenon is a function of the antibiotic concentration outside the cells. We present in this paper: --Bacteria growth and cell division behaviour--Effect of sub-inhibitory dihydrostreptomycin concentration on E. coli growth--(3H) dihydrostreptomycin incorporation.

TitleMain.Title: Halon 1301 human inhalation study. Final report.
TitleMain.OtherInformation: NASA Johnson Space Center, Space and Life Sciences Directorate, Medical Sciences Division.

Author.CollectiveName: United States. National Aeronautics and Space Administration. Space and Life Sciences Directorate.

PublicationInfo.Imprint: Houston, TX : NASA Johnson Space Center, 1989.

Abstract.AbstractText: Halon 1301 is used as the fire-extinguishing agent aboard the Space Shuttle. Several flight scenarios exist in which Halon 1301 could be released into the atmosphere even in the absence of fire. If Halon 1301 were released, the crew module atmosphere could contain a 1 percent Halon 1301 concentration. This was felt to be a worst-case operational environment. To examine the effects of this concentration on physiological and mental performance, NASA sponsored a human inhalation study. Four pairs of subjects were each exposed to air and to 1 percent Halon 1301 in a double-blind manner. To evaluate cognitive and motor performance, the Essex Automated Portable Test System was administered eight times during each exposure. To evaluate physiological response, blood and urine samples were collected for clinical chemistry analyses, and vital signs, including pulmonary function, were measured before, during, and after the exposures. Blood and breath samples were also collected to provide dosimetric and toxicokinetic information on Halon 1301 in humans. Data from the toxicokinetic study indicated that during exposure blood Halon 1301 levels tended to increase rapidly and approach a steady-state concentration (approximately 3-4 micrograms/ml) within 1 hour. Halon 1301 levels in the breath samples reflected the chamber concentrations relatively closely. Results of the physiological and medical evaluation indicated that there was a statistically significant change from baseline for one serum chemistry variable, three hematological variables, one urinalysis variable, and one spirometry variable. The values for these variables, though statistically significant, were all within clinically acceptable ranges. Results of the performance testing indicated that there was a < 4 percent change from baseline. Although it is statistically significant, the change is so small that a crewmember's ability to pilot the spacecraft or to perform other mission-critical tasks should not be affected in the event of a 24-hour exposure to 1 percent Halon 1301.

TitleMain.Title: 13C specific labeling of lignin in intact plants

Author.CollectiveName: Chemical Congress of North America (3rd : 1988 Jun 5-11 : Toronto, Canada); National Meeting of the American Chemical Society

Investigator.Affiliation: Non-NASA center: VPI, Blacksburg, Dept Wood Sci. Department of Wood Science, Virginia Polytechnic Institute and State University, Blacksburg 24061, USA.

Abstract.AbstractText: Lignin deposition processes in Leucaena leucocephala and Triticum aestivum L. have been monitored in situ, following administration to the growing plants of various specifically-labelled C-13 lignin precursors and analysis of the resulting plant tissue by solid state carbon-13 nuclear magnetic resonance spectroscopy. The results obtained were compared to those obtained with artificial dehydrogenatively polymerized (DHP) lignins, long thought to more or less represent lignin structure. For L. leucocephala plant tissue, it was found that the dominant bonding environment of lignin corresponded to 2-O-4' (so-called beta-O-4) linkages. Importantly, bond frequencies were very different when compared to artificial synthetic preparations. Surprisingly, lignified T. aestivum tissue provided very different results, and no significant contribution due to beta-O-4 bonding was evident. This underscored the point that lignins vary greatly in structure depending upon the plant species under investigation. It was also found that significant bonding occurred at C3 (so-called C alpha) to other constituents, presumed to be mainly of carbohydrate origin. These results again showed the limitation of DHP polymers as adequate representation of lignin structure in situ.

KeywordList.Keyword: Non-NASA Center VPI, Blacksburg, Dept Wood Sci

TitleMain.Title: A 1 Hz resolution RFI survey : preliminary results
TitleMain.OtherInformation: / J.W. Dreher, J. Tarter, D. Werthimer.

Abstract.AbstractText: In support of the nascent SETI Microwave Observing Project at NASA, radio-frequency interference (RFI) data with a resolution of 1 Hz and an integration time of 1 second were collected at several radio observatories during the last year. At each site, we surveyed a frequency range of > 10 MHz over the course of a few days, with the antenna stowed. The threshold for the detection of RFI was -164 dBm into 1 Hz for the first two telescopes and -173 dBm for the NRAO telescope. Data with less sensitivity but much better frequency and time coverage, obtained with a scanning spectrum analyzer at kHz resolutions and a horizon-sensitive surveillance antenna, are presented in an accompanying paper in this Symposium by Olsen et al.

TitleMain.Title: Baroreflex sensitivity and its [correction of it's] components during the phenylephrine test in healthy young subjects

Author.CollectiveName: European Symposium on Life Sciences Research in Space

PublicationInfo.Imprint: Noordwijk, The Netherlands : ESA Publ. Div., 1996.

Abstract.AbstractText: Assessment of baroreflex sensitivity (BRS) has been increasingly used in experimental and clinical cardiology. In this study we evaluated determinants of BRS and its components in healthy, young subjects. The study population consisted of 44 healthy, normal-weighted, non-smoking male and female subjects aged 23-40 years. Baroreflex sensitivity was measured using phenylephrine bolus injection technique. In addition to BRS, R-R interval and systolic blood pressure responses during the phenylephrine test were analysed separately. Frequency domain analysis of heart rate variability and exercise test were also performed. In the univariate analysis BRS correlated with weight (r=0.30, p<0.05), mean R-R interval (r=0.33, p<0.05), exercise capacity (r=0.34, p<0.05) and high frequency component of heart rate variability (r=0.32, p<0.05). In addition, BRS was significantly higher in men than in women (23.4 +/- 1.8 vs 15.6 +/- 1.7 ms/mmHg, p<0.01). This was predominantly due to greater rise in systolic pressure induced by phenylephrine. The determinants of the components of BRS were strikingly different: R-R interval response during phenylephrine test was associated with weight, mean R-R interval, heart rate variability, body mass index and systolic blood pressure, whereas systolic blood pressure was associated only with exercise capacity and gender. We conclude that the components of BRS provide important and complementary information about cardiovascular regulation, which may be useful in studying the disorders of autonomic dysfunction related to different physiological and pathological conditions.

PGBA features include atmosphere, temperature, and humidity control; plant support; and plant support nutrient packs. TitleMain.Title: Statoliths, cytoskeletal elements and cytoplasmic streaming of Chara rhizoids under reduced gravity during TEXUS flights
TitleMain.OtherInformation: / B. Buchen, M. Braun & A. Sievers.

PublicationInfo.Imprint: Noordwijk, The Netherlands : ESA Publ. Div., 1997.

Abstract.AbstractText: The weightless statoliths in the rhizoids of the green alga Chara move towards the cell base (opposite to the originally acting gravity vector) during TEXUS rocket parabolic flights. After destruction of the cytoskeletal actin filaments by specific drugs, however, the statoliths are not basipetally transported under microgravity. The displacement of statoliths under microgravity is greater in the axial direction than laterally. Thus it has been proved for the first time that, under 1 g, the statoliths exert tensional forces on actin filaments and that a balance of forces (of gravity and the counteracting force mediated by actin filaments) is responsible for the correct positioning of the statoliths in the rhizoid, guaranteeing the ability to respond to the gravity vector.

TitleMain.Title: Taiwan's family planning in charts.

Author.CollectiveName: Taiwan. Provincial Department of Health. Institute of Family Planning.

PublicationInfo.Imprint: Taichung, Taiwan, Institute of Family Planning, Provincial Department of Health, 1969.
PublicationInfo.Place: Taichung, Taiwan, Institute of Family Planning, Provincial Department of Health,

OtherAbstract.AbstractText: This report of Taiwan's family planning program from 1967 to 1969 charts economic, geographic, and demographic factors as well as program organization and results. In 1969, the Government approved the Republic of China's Population Policy and the Institute of Family Planning was created within the Provincial Health Department to continue efforts begun by previous agencies. By mid-1969, Taiwan's population total 14 million reflecting a decline in the birth rate from 36 (1963) to 29 per 1000. 42% of the population is below the age of 15. The mean age of women at marriage is 23 years and men average 26 years. The IUD (Lippes loop) continues as the major contraceptive method but removal rates have been high. Retenion rates for 550,000 insertions were 67% after year 1, 51% after year 2, and 40% after year 3. The birth rate among IUD acceptors over 30 years of age was less than 10 per 100 compared with 30 per 100 among noncontraceptive users. Since 1967 women losing their IUDs have been encouraged to use oral contraceptives. By mid-1969, 80,000 women had accepted the pill, but continuation rates have been low -- 49% after 6 months 31% after 1 year. Total government cost for education and IUD insertion has averaged between $4 and 5$ per woman. Oral contraceptives supplied by the Pathfinder Fund are distributed free or with a service charge of 25 cents. From 1967 to 1969, commercial pill sales rose from 30-40,000 to 45-50,000 cycles per month. Taiwan hopes to reduce the annual population growth rate from 2.4 to 2 by 1973. Future family planning efforts will concentrate on women under 30 years of age and emphasize child-spacing concepts as well as an ideal family size of 2 to 3 children.

TitleMain.Title: Death control

OtherAbstract.AbstractText: The present population explosion worldwide was caused primarily by a lag between a slowly declining fertility rate and a sharply declining mortality rate. Mortality throughout history is discussed. Prescientific medicine, modern medicine and drugs, and preventive medicine and their relationship to mortality are discussed. Ways of measuring mortality are explained. The result of modern medical and sanitary improvements has been lowered national death rates worldwide, illustrated by mortality and life expectancy tables. Laws and medical services which affect health in different countries are summarized. Differential mortality among various groups in a nation, especially when this involves high maternal and infant mortality, is a cause of concern.

TitleMain.Title: VASeal (Promotional material).

OtherAbstract.AbstractText: The VASeal is a bipolar electrocautery instrument development for the Schmidt vasectomy technique in which electrocautery seals the cut ends of the vas. Electrocautery of the vas reduces incidence of granuloma and spontaneous reanastomosis. The VASeal bipolar electrode has 2 annular elements which make uniform contacts with mucosa around the circumference of the human. The resistance to current flow increases so less energy is available to coagulate deeper tissues. The VASeal is, therefore, a self-limiting process. The VASeal kit consists of 1 power unit, 1 hand control, 2 bipolar needles, and one operators manual. The system weighs 21 pounds and is battery powered.

TitleMain.Title: Cost-effectiveness of family planning : overview of the literature
TitleMain.OtherInformation: / D.G. Gillespie, M.E. Mamlouk, K.M. Chen.

OtherAbstract.AbstractText: In this overview of the literature on cost effectiveness analysis (CEA) of family planning programs every effort was made to undertake a comprehensive review of the literature. Several POPLINE and DIALOG searches were conducted. US Agency for International Development (AID) files were reviewed for unpublished material, and relevant references from publications were located. Several hundred documents were reviewed, but only 73 studies were found to actually present the results of cost effectiveness analysis. A study was included in this review if it included a cost effectiveness ratio. Only studies that addressed family planning efforts in developing countries are included in the review, i.e., the geographical regions represented in the studies reflect the evolution of family planning. The studies report on Asian programs 81 times, on Latin American programs 33 times, on Near East countries 18 times, and on Africa 11 times. It is difficult to generalize about the cost effectiveness results found in this review. The 73 studies not only varied in their approach to cost effectiveness but in the quality of their approaches. In 36, or 49%, of the studies the reader can replicate the authors' computations for obtaining cost effectiveness ratios. In 29 (40%) of the studies the information was insufficient for replicating the computations. The remaining 8 (11%) studies had insufficient data for the reader to follow all the steps of the authors' cost effectiveness analysis but did provide enough information for partial replication. The most commonly used cost effectiveness ratio was cost per acceptor. The principal merit of the cost per acceptor measurement is its relative ease of calculation, but it has limited value in terms of telling one how a program is progressing toward its objectives. Its value is even less in comparing 1 program with another. Cost per new acceptor is somewhat more sensitive than cost per acceptor since it indicates what marginal cost was required for a program to grow during a particular period. There is a general decline in the cost per output since previous years' investments still have a payoff in subsequent years. A decreasing cost per output is not uniformly evident and cannot be invariably expected. In some instances, sharp increases are clearly explained. Of the 73 studies reviewed, 24 presented other types of cost effectiveness (CE) ratios in addition to or in place of cost per acceptor or new acceptor, cost per couple year protection, cost per birth averted, and cost per clinic/home service visit. These ratios fall into 3 broad categories: client population; operations; and outputs.

NLMCatalogRecord.GeneralNote: Presented at the International Workshop on Cost-Effectiveness Analysis and Cost-Benefit Analysis in Family Planning Programs, St. Michaels, Maryland, August 17-20, 1981.

TitleMain.Title: Procedures for assessing the cost-effectiveness of a diarrheal disease control program based on oral rehydration therapy

OtherAbstract.AbstractText: Major uses of a cost effectiveness analysis of an oral rehydration therapy (ORT) program are to structure systematically the content, resources, and impact of an ORT program, to compare investments in ORT programs with those in alternative health programs (curative and preventive), to compare alternative approaches to delivering ORT (e.g., home versus centers), to forecast the implications of modifications to the program on its cost and health effects and develop recommendations, and to evaluate the achievements of a current or past program. Information required for a cost effectiveness analysis include data to estimate program costs -- personnel (salary and share of time for ORT), supplies (quantity and unit cost), indirect costs (supervision, maintenance, and use of facilities), and other. Data to estimate program health effects are the ideal -- field trial with direct monitoring of mortality -- and short-term, i.e., the epidemiologic model. Tables present the deaths averted by use of ORT in various studies, a household survey form on incidence and treatment of diarrhea, a worksheet for determining salary costs of ORT program, elements of a conceptual matrix of ORT program costs, a worksheet for estimating cost effectiveness, and cost effectiveness of selected health interventions in developing countries.

TitleMain.Title: Information retrieval in developing countries : bibliographic data bases in Latin America, especially Brazil

PublicationInfo.Imprint: New York, New York, Association for Population/Family Planning Libraries and Information Centers-International, 1986.
PublicationInfo.Place: New York, New York, Association for Population/Family Planning Libraries and Information Centers-International,

OtherAbstract.AbstractText: Sawyer outlines the distribution of computerized bibliographic databases in developing countries. The systems which exist, in addition to POPLINE, which is based in the US, are in Latin America, Africa, and Asia, with each country having 2 individual systems. 1 of the oldest systems outside the US is DOCPAL in Santiago, Chile, at Centro Latinamericano de Demografia. DOCPOP began in 1982 in Sao Paulo, Brazil and publishes REVISTA DOCPOP. In Africa, there is PIDSA (Population Information and Documentation System for Africa), located in Accra, Ghana. The Sahel Institute in Bamako, Africa has RESADOC, which is semicomputerized with work done in Senegal. An Arab League Population Unit in Tunis is equivalent to PIDSA. In Asia there is EBIS/POPFILE, which produces ADOPT (Asian Pacific and Worldwide Documents on Population Topics), an abstract journal. There is hope to start up a system in Malaysia called MANPINS. There is a miniature DOCPAL in the Dominican Republic which, so far, is manual. The National Population Council in Mexico and the National Population Council in Peru are considering setting up bibliographic systems. The author concludes with a case study of DOCPOP. A look at cumulative citations, indexing, and abstracts written in 1982-1984 shows that indexing keeps up the citations; it is much harder to keep up with the abstracts. It takes about 10 minutes to write the citation and to index, but about 1/3 of an hour to prepare an abstract. There were about 5 literature search requests/month for DOCPOP from 1983-1985. Almost 3000 abstracts were published in REVISTA DOCPOP between 1982 and 1985. The largest user was the state of Sao Paulo. Some hypotheses explaining what is happening in the demographic literature within Brazil include: 1) there are fewer citations in Brazil than in developed countries; 2) citations in Brazil are increasing; 3) there are more citations of sources in English than in French; and 4) there are few citations in Latin American literature.

TitleMain.Title: 1962 Pro-Familia 1987. 25 anos sirviendo a la familia. Fomentando la paternidad y maternidad responsables. Borrando prejuicios. Abriendo mentes. Despertando conciencias. Sensibilizando corazones.

TitleOther.TitleAlternate: 1962 Pro-Familia 1987. 25 years of service to the family. Promoting responsible fatherhood and motherhood. Erasing prejudices. Opening minds. Awakening consciences. Sensitizing hearts.

PublicationInfo.Imprint: [San Salvador, El Salvador], Asociacion Demografica Salvadorena, [1988].
PublicationInfo.Place: [San Salvador, El Salvador], Asociacion Demografica Salvadorena,

OtherAbstract.AbstractText: Among the great achievements to which the Salvadoran Demographic Association (ADS) contributed in its 1st 25 years of existence were public acceptance in El Salvador of family planning as a tool of responsible parenthood, the decline of family size from about 7 in the 1950s to 4.4 in 1985, and the use of contraception by about 1/2 of women in union. Despite political and religious opposition and an unfavorable press, the Association succeeded in developing services and influencing the opinion of decision makers so that now El Salvador has adopted a family planning policy and has integrated family planning into maternal-child health services. The ADS now has 4 clinics in different cities, a family planning library, and 706 contraceptive distribution posts attended by volunteers in rural communities. The social marketing program distributes contraceptives in 900 pharmacies, 1015 stores, 88 agricultural services, and 70 motels. 280 machines dispense condoms. Some 200 businesses contribute funds and materials to ADS, and about 1000 individuals provide volunteer IEC services in the community. ADS has been a member of the International Planned Parenthood Federation since 1971. Between 1950-85, El Salvador's crude birth rate declined from 49.1 to 36.3/1000, the crude death rate declined from 19.7 to 8.4/1000, and the annual rate of growth declined from 2.6 to 1.9%. But rural fertility is still much higher than that in urban areas. The total population increased from 1,939,800 in 1950 to 4,933,833 in 1987. The opening of the 1st ADS clinic demonstrated the pressing need of the population for family planning information and services. The ADS also provides surgical contraception, gynecologic examinations, and cervical cytology. ADS initiated training programs in contraception, population and development, reproductive physiology, and sex education. The Association has conducted 4 national surveys of family health. The most recent survey in 1985 showed that 89% of Salvadoran women knew a contraceptive method. 47.3% of women in union used a method, with 31.8% using female sterilization, 6.6% pills, 3.3% IUDs, 1.9% rhythm, and 1.2% condoms.

TitleMain.Title: Annex to Research Priorities : Behavioural Research (needed research with priority suggestions and initial emphasis on pattern II countries, ** very high priority, * high priority)

PublicationInfo.Imprint: Canberra, Australia, Australian National University, National Centre for Epidemiology and Population Health, Health Transition Centre, 1990.
PublicationInfo.Place: Canberra, Australia, Australian National University, National Centre for Epidemiology and Population Health, Health Transition Centre,

OtherAbstract.AbstractText: This document discusses establishing national capacities to conduct behavioral research of topics on women and HIV/AIDS, methodological priorities, and studies appropriate to any Pattern II countries as well as those appropriate to Pattern II countries with major AIDS epidemics. Intervention impact research and research on Pattern I societies are also discussed. When exploring all Pattern II countries, research may examine knowledge, treatment, basic behavior, belief systems with regard to AIDS, communication, blood transfusions, iv drug use, clitoridectomy, changes in women's situations, the economics of sexual networking, and broad changes in the nature of sexual networking. Under epidemic conditions, additional studies might examine the disease's impact upon the family, the individual, caring for the sick, community dislocation, changing demography, women health providers, other duties of the health care system, and the family planning movement. Other research would assess the impact of educational campaigns, advocacy of social change, target interventions, women's employment schemes, social service support, women and community empowerment, intensive campaigns against sexually transmitted diseases, door-to-door counseling, and the primary health approach.

NLMCatalogRecord.GeneralNote: Prepared for World Health Organization, Global Programme on AIDS: Meeting on Research Priorities regarding Women and AIDS, WHO, Geneva, 19-20 November, 1990.

TitleMain.Title: Policymaker's chartbook on world population issues.

OtherAbstract.AbstractText: The Policymakers Chartbook on World Population Issues provides statistical charts by region or country on world population trends and projections, family planning (FP) programs, birth control technology, FP and family welfare, population impact on poverty, population impact on the environment, and trends in donor support. A few brief statements accompany each chart. Specific charts on population details population growth from the year 0-2050, annual world population growth rates from 1900-95, relative change in population in developing countries from 1950-2020, annual population increments by region in 1991, largest annual population increments in 1991 in 25 countries which accounts for 80% of growth (India, China, Pakistan, Nigeria, Indonesia, Brazil, Bangladesh, former USSR, US, Mexico, Iran, Philippines, Egypt, Ethiopia, Vietnam, Turkey. Zaire, South Africa, Tanzania, Kenya, Myanmar, Thailand, Sudan, Algeria, and Colombia), world population by region in 1990 and 2025, income/capita compared to population growth rates and doubling times for 17 countries, alternate population projections in 1990-2025 (India, Nigeria, and Mexico), and growth of 13 selected large cities. Charts on organized FP include the time span for fertility reduction for 7 selected countries, average family size declines in Latin America and Africa and Asia, the percentage of childbearing married women who desired stoppage or postponement of childbearing, changes in key indicators of FP, developing countries by type of population policy (none but subsidize FP, no support for FP or restrictions on contraception, or supportive FP policies), FP expenditures by donors and developing country governments and foreign aid donors, and comparison of current with projected FP expenditures for the year 2000. Effective contraceptive usage, failure rates, annual maternal deaths from contraceptive use and unintended pregnancy in low income developing countries by age group, abortion law type (restrictive, moderate) by country and region, private sector costs of condoms and oral contraceptives and female contraceptive sterilization for selective countries charts are also included. Other charts are available on infant and maternal mortality for selected countries and family size, educational attainment, and wealth accumulation for Thailand. Poverty alleviation charts include world grain production, age group and dependency burden, labor force, and gross national product/capita. Environment maps reveal population pressure on tropical forests, and land degradation at risk, and charts show estimated water supply and greenhouse gas emission. Donors are listed by country.

TitleMain.Title: 19-23 April 1999, Preschoolers Health Week. Garantisadong Pambata. Proposed strategy for communication and creative materials

OtherAbstract.AbstractText: This paper proposes a strategy and provides materials for motivating mothers or care givers to bring their children, ages up to 6 years old, to the nearest government health center or hospital for vitamin A supplementation, routine immunization, polio vaccination, weighing, and deworming. This strategy of communication embraces the need for incorporating activities and messages of the intended audiences' environment. The summary of communication strategies involves social mobilization, conceptualization and production of creative materials, interpersonal communication, media relations, socio-political event (kick-off activity), enter-educate activity (culminating activity), and communication research. The preliminary creative materials include an implementation guide, press kit, health advisory, and printed T-shirts and a cap. Also disclosed was the format of the draft letter and program for the donors' meeting, lists of potential sponsors/donors, a proposed media plan, list of media practitioners, and a communication research proposal.

TitleMain.Title: Essays in the history of eugenics : proceedings of a conference organised by the Galton Institute, London, 1997

OtherAbstract.AbstractText: These are the proceedings of a conference devoted to the history and achievements of the Galton Institute, founded in 1907 as the Eugenics Education Society. The first three papers examine the development of the eugenics movement in the United Kingdom and its efforts to apply scientific ideas to the problems of society. Particular attention is given to the relationship between the eugenics and the birth control movements. The remainder of the papers examine the role of eugenics in the development of several disciplines, including demography, human genetics, psychometrics, and biometry. There are also two papers on eugenics in France and Scandinavia, and in the United States.
